IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 8925 S1381-1169(13)00415-9 10.1016/j.molcata.2013.11.003 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Reaction of hydrogenation of m-dinitrobenzene on metal catalysts. Fig. 2 X-ray patterns of the supported Au catalysts: (a) Au/SiO2, (b) Au/Fe3O4, and (c) Au/Fe3O4-SiO2. Note: peak assignments: (■) Fe3O4, (○) γ-Fe2O3, (▵) Au, and (●) SiO2. Fig. 3 N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of supports and catalysts used: (a) Fe3O4, (b) Au/Fe3O4, (c) Fe3O4-SiO2, and (d) Au/Fe3O4-SiO2. Fig. 4 Room temperature magnetic hysteresis loops of (a) Fe3O4, (b) Fe3O4-SiO2, (c) Au/Fe3O4, and (d) Au/Fe3O4-SiO2. Inset in (a)–(d): magnified part of their original curve from −1 to 1×103 Oe. Fig. 5 TPR profiles of (a) Au/SiO2, (b) Au/Fe3O4, (c) Au/Fe3O4-SiO2, (d) Fe3O4, and (e) SiO2-Fe3O4. Fig. 6 XPS spectra in the region of Au 4f 7/2 for the reduced catalysts. Fig. 7 m-DNB hydrogenation at 363K and 4MPa. Conversion levels as a function of time for (■) Au/Fe3O4, (▴) Au/Fe3O4-SiO2, and (○) Au/SiO2. Fig. 8 Conversion (%) vs. yield products: (■) Au/Fe3O4, (▴) Au/Fe3O4-SiO2, and (○) Au/SiO2. Fig. 9 Recyclability cycles of the Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 catalyst in a series of subsequent reaction–separation steps. The symbols indicate: (■) % conversion of m-DNB at 90min, (▵) % yield to m-PDA, (○) % yield to m-NA, and (□) % yield to m-HA. Table 1 Gold content in the catalysts and crystallite size of Au and Fe3O4 catalysts calculated by the Debye–Scherrer equation. Martínez a ⁎ Hugo Rojas a Lizbeth Vargas a Carlos Parra a María H. Brijaldo b Fabio B. Passos b a Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Pedagógica y Tecnológica de Colombia UPTC, Avenida Central del Norte, Vía Paipa, Tunja, Boyac, Colombia Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Pedagógica y Tecnológica de Colombia UPTC Avenida Central del Norte, Vía Paipa Tunja Boyac Colombia b Departamento de Engenharia Química, Universidade Federal Fluminense, R. Passos da Pátria, 156, Niterói, RJ 24210-240, Brasil Departamento de Engenharia Química, Universidade Federal Fluminense R. Passos da Pátria, 156 Niterói RJ 24210-240 Brasil ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +57987432800. Graphical abstract The catalytic hydrogenation of m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB) was studied using Au catalysts supported on oxides with magnetic properties. The catalysts were characterized by magnetic susceptibility measurements, XRD, N2 adsorption, TPR, and XPS analysis. The results showed that the gold nanoparticles supported on Fe3O4-SiO2 led to the formation of Au δ– sites. However, this type of site did not alter the catalytic behavior. The catalysts showed high activity and were easily separable. The presence of Fe n+ sites prevented the formation of intermediate hydroxylamines. Keywords m-Dinitrobenzene Au/Fe3O4 Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 1 Introduction The hydrogenation of aromatic nitro compounds with heterogeneous catalysts is usuallythe method for the production of their corresponding anilines [1,2], which represent important intermediates in the manufacture of numerous organic molecules and are primarily used in the synthesis of aromatic amines and substituted aromatic amines [3]. The traditional manufacture route, known as the Béchamp process, is not a sustainable process due to the production of large quantities of toxic iron oxides [3]. One example is the hydrogenation of m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB) to m-phenylenediamine (m-PDA), which proceeds via the formation of m-nitroaniline (m-NA). However, an undesirable accumulation of intermediates, principally hydroxylamines, is produced with conventional catalysts [4,5]. The first hydrogenation step leading to the nitroso compound, and secondly the consecutive hydrogenation leading to the first hydroxylamine intermediates. The hydrogenation of this later produces m-nitroaniline. This same mechanism is followed by the other NO2 group, as can be seen in Fig. 1 . Supported gold catalysts can show very high activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of m-DNB [6,7]. Gold clusters with a diameter below 2nm are essential to obtain a high activity and selectivity in hydrogenation reactions [8,9]; however, in the hydrogenation of m-DNB, the electronic character of nanoscale Au determines the reactant activation step [6,7]. The adsorption of m-DNB on Au δ– sites leads preferentially to the formation of m-PDA, while the adsorption of m-DNB on Au δ+ sites favors the formation of m-NA. Cardenas et al. [6,7] reported that the adsorption of m-DNB on Au δ– sites resulted in a repulsion between π-delocalized electrons and that partially (negatively)-charged Au led to resonance structures with two positive localized charges on the ring where both NO2 groups are activated, finally resulting in the formation of m-PDA by nucleophilic attack of molecular H2. The extra electron density on Au δ– sites may enable gold clusters to function as hydrogenation catalysts [10]; this type of Au δ– charged species on Au catalysts is observed after treatment in flowing H2 [11,12] for reducible and non-reducible supports [6,11–13]. On the other hand, separation and recycling are essential steps that affect the overall process economics. Thus, separation by applying an external magnetic field has stimulated an intensive study of materials with magnetic properties that easily allow the separation of the catalyst [14,15]. Generally, magnetic materials using silica as a protective shell or core-shell can be employed as magnetic supports. In this study, gold catalysts were supported on Fe3O4 nanoparticles and Fe3O4-SiO2 core-shell composites. The solids were reduced in an H2 atmosphere with the aim of assuring the formation of Au δ– sites and favoring the formation of m-phenylenediamine (m-PDA). Thus, it is possible to control the partial or total hydrogenation of nitroaromatics with the advantage of easy magnetic separation and reuse possibility. An Au/SiO2 catalyst prepared by deposition–precipitation with NH4OH was used for comparison. It has been reported that on Au/SiO2 prepared by deposition–precipitation with aqueous ammonia, Au δ– charged species were formed [11,12]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O) (Analyticals, 99%), ethylene glycol (Merck, 99.5%), sodium acetate (Merck, 99%), ethanol (J.T. Baker, 99.98%), NH3·H2O (J.T. Baker, 37%), tetraethyl orthosilicate, TEOS (Fluka, 99%), fumed silica (Syloid 266 Grace Davidson), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 99%), HAuCl4 (Aldrich >99%), urea (J.T. Baker, 99.3%), and m-dinitrobenzene (Aldrich >97%) were used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The magnetic microspheres were synthesized using a solvothermal method [16]. Briefly, 2.70g of FeCl3·6H2O was dissolved in 100mL of ethylene glycol under magnetic stirring. A yellow clear solution was obtained after stirring for 0.5h. Then, 7.20g of CH3CO2Na (sodium acetate) was added to this solution, and it was stirred for 0.5h. The resultant solution was subjected to hydrothermal treatment at 373K for 16h. The precipitate of magnetic microspheres was centrifuged, washed with ethanol, and deionized water, followed by drying at 333K. The molar ratio of acetate/Fe3+ ions was equal to 3. The encapsulation of the magnetic microspheres with SiO2 was performed using the Stöber method [17]. In a typical preparation, Fe3O4 particles were dispersed in a mixture of ethanol (400mL), deionized water (100mL), and concentrated ammonia aqueous solution (6mL) by ultrasonication for 2h. Subsequently, 3.5mL of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added drop wise and stirred for 3h. The products were filtered, washed with deionized water, and then dried under vacuum at 333K for further use. The molar ratio between the magnetic particles and the source of silica was 1:1. This solid was called Fe3O4-SiO2. Au/Fe3O4 catalyst (1wt.% nominal) was prepared by the deposition–precipitation method with urea (DPU) [18]. Briefly, Fe3O4 nanoparticles were added to an aqueous solution containing HAuCl4 and urea. The suspension was maintained at 353K and vigorously stirred for 16h. After the deposition–precipitation procedure, the sample was washed with water then centrifuged and dried under vacuum. Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 and Au/SiO2 (1wt.% nominal) catalysts were synthesized by deposition–precipitation method with aqueous ammonia [19]. Before preparation, SiO2 was calcined at 773K for 3h. A solution was added to the support in order to give an Au loading of 1wt.%, which was stirred for 2h at 353K and then cooled down to room temperature; 1M NH4OH solution was added and left for 3h without agitation. The solid was centrifuged and washed with deionized water and dried under vacuum at 373K. All catalysts prior to characterization or catalytic testing were reduced in flowing hydrogen (30mL/min) at 573K for 2h. In order to remove Cl− ions, the reduction was carried out in the presence of water at 0.031MPa pressure. 2.3 Characterization The content of deposited gold was determined by atomic absorption analysis. Previously the sample was digested with aqua regia HCl–HNO3 (3:1 by volume). Elemental analysis was done using an atomic absorption spectrometer (AAnalyst 3110, PerkinElmer) at a wavelength of 242.8nm. The Au loading of the samples was expressed in grams of Au per gram of sample. The X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out with a Rigaku MiniFlex II using Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54056Å). The XRD diffractograms were recorded in the 2θ range of 20–80̊, using a counter time of 1s and a step size of 0.05̊. Crystallite sizes were calculated from the line broadening of the main XRD peaks by using the Debye–Scherrer equation. The textural properties of the sample were determined by N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77K measured in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. Samples were previously evacuated at 623K for 4h. The BET method was used to calculate the total surface area of the samples. Magnetization measurements were performed in a Vibrating Sample Magnetometer (VSM)–VersaLab device at 300K. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed in Micromeritics Autochem-2920 equipment under a flow of 30mL/min using 5% H2/Ar gas mixture, raising the temperature at a heating rate of 10K/min upto 1073K. The XPS data were obtained in a Thermo Scientific Escalab 250 XI spectrometer. Measurements were performed at room temperature with monochromatic Al Kα (hv =1486.6eV) radiation. The analyzer was operated at 25eV pass energy and a step size 0.05eV. The pressure in the analytical chamber was 6.3×10−9 mbar. C 1s signal (284.6eV) was used as an internal energy reference in all experiments. Determination of core-level peak positions was accomplished after background subtraction using peak XPS software. Peaks in a spectrum were fitted by a combination of Gauss and Lorentz curves, which also allowed overlapping peaks to be separated. 2.4 Catalytic studies Hydrogenation in liquid phase reactions was carried out in a batch type reactor at a constant stirring rate (1000rpm) under the following conditions: hydrogen partial pressure of 4MPa, catalyst sample 100mg, 25mL of a 0.02M solution in ethanol, and reaction temperature of 313K. The catalyst and substrate dissolved in ethanol were introduced into the batch reactor and purged with He and immediately pressurized with hydrogen at 4MPa. Reaction products were analyzed in a GC-Varian 3800 equipped with a β-DEX column with He as a carrier and a constant temperature of 393K. The response variables were the conversion of m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB) and yield (%) of m-phenylenediamine (m-PDA) or m-nitroaniline (m-NA), because this reaction is consecutive. The Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 catalyst was reused in the four cycles of hydrogenation of m-DNB. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Table 1 shows the actual loading of gold in the studied catalysts. Deposition–precipitation with NH4OH employed for Au/SiO2 and Au/SiO2-Fe3O4 allows a high efficiency of gold deposition, close to 90%, as previously reported [19,20]. Similarly, deposition–precipitation with urea (DPU) makes a high deposition of gold in Fe3O4 possible. Fig. 2 shows the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of reduced Au catalysts. It can be seen that the Au/SiO2 catalyst exhibits a broad XRD peak assigned to the amorphous silica, and a signal near to 2θ =38.18̊ (111) and 44.38̊ (200) due to the presence of crystallites of gold (JCPDS 04-0784). These signals are also shown in the Au/Fe3O4 and Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 catalysts. The (111) reflection was chosen to calculate the crystallite size of Au catalysts using the Debye–Scherrer equation (Table 1). The gold particle size is similar for Au/Fe3O4 and Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 catalysts. For Au/SiO2, the value of particle size calculated by DRX is similar to that obtained by TEM measurements [12]. Fig. 2(b) and (c) clearly shows the reflections characteristic of cubic inverse spinel Fe3O4 NPs (JCPDS 89-0950). However, γ-Fe2O3 (JCPDS 33-0664) has a crystal structure and lattice spacing similar to Fe3O4. As a result of the difference between the experimental d-value and the intensity of lines, it can be stated that the XRD patterns correspond to Fe3O4 NPs. The crystal size of the Fe3O4 using the (311) reflection peak at 2θ =35.5̊ indicates that the crystallinity of Fe3O4 cores persists after SiO2 coating. Fig. 3 shows the isotherms of adsorption and desorption of the supports and Au catalysts. For Fe3O4 and Au/Fe3O4, the adsorption isotherms were type IV, in agreement with the Brunauer, Deming, Deming and Teller (BDDT) classification. Table 2 summarizes the textural properties of the supports and catalysts obtained from the N2 isotherms of adsorption–desorption at 77K. The value of the surface area (S BET) of Au/Fe3O4 catalyst could be associated with the introduction of gold particles that produces an increase in the porosity caused by the deagglomeration of Fe3O4 particles by gold particles. A type IV isotherm was observed with the deposition of silica over the nanoparticles of Fe3O4. The silica coating increased the textural properties of the Fe3O4 particles, and the observed values of pore volume and pore size for these materials are consistent with those of a mesoporous material (Table 1). Fig. 4 displays the typical magnetization curves as a function of magnetic field of the supports and Au catalysts supported on Fe3O4 and Fe3O4-SiO2. It can be seen that all of the curves pass through the origin, resulting in solids that can be easily dispersed when the applied magnetic field is removed. This explains why in Fe3O4-SiO2, where there is a coating of silica on the magnetic particles, this magnetic response remains, and can be easily separated with a magnet. The measured coercive field (H c), saturation magnetization (M s), and saturation field (H s) values are summarized in Table 3 . The M s value of Fe3O4 is higher than that of Fe3O4-SiO2, Au/Fe3O4, and Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 nanocomposites due to the existence of silica or gold coating. However, the magnetization shown by Au/Fe3O4 and Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 permits the complete separation of the catalyst with a commercial magnet. Fig. 5 displays the temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) profiles of supports and calcined catalysts. The Au/SiO2 sample (Fig. 5(a)) displays a low hydrogen consumption observed around 380K ascribed to the reduction of gold oxide. When gold is supported on Fe3O4, the peak of reduction of gold oxide appears at 370K (Fig. 5(b)), while the step of reduction takes place at 380K for Au/Fe3O4-SiO2. In solids containing Fe3O4, the gold reduction is followed by two reduction peaks at 553and 583K, which are associated with a reduction of Fe species. Fig. 5(d) and (e) shows the reduction profiles of Fe3O4 and Fe3O4-SiO2 supports. The reduction of iron oxide species takes place at temperatures higher than 400K, considering the following steps Fe2O3 →Fe3O4 →FeO→Fe [21–23]. Magnetite is a well-known mixed oxide; thus, the reduction to FeO presents two steps (Fig. 5(d)). In the reduction of the oxide encapsulated (Fe3O4-SiO2), only a peak corresponding to FeO is observed (Fig. 5(e)), which is explained due to the fact that the peak is broad and can contain the envelope of this transition. In the presence of gold, this reduction step takes place at a lower temperature (550K), which is attributed to spillover of hydrogen from gold to iron oxide species (Fig. 5(b) and (c)). This is clearly observed in Au/Fe3O4 catalyst. The reduction step of FeO→Fe begins to 624K, as can be observed in Fig. 4(b) and (d). Fig. 6 displays XPS spectra in the region of Au 4f 7/2 for the reduced catalysts. The Au 4f is characterized by the doublet of two spin orbit components, viz., Au 4f 7/2 and Au 4f 5/2. In the following, the values of binding energy (BE) will refer to the Au 4f 7/2 peak for comparison with previous reports [24]. In the Au/Fe3O4 catalyst, the binding energy is 83.8eV, which is characteristic of Au0 [24]; other species such as Au3+ were not evidenced after the deconvolution of XPS spectra of Au/Fe3O4. Visco et al. [24] indicated that for Au/Fe2O3 catalysts obtained by co-precipitation and after treatment at 573K in H2, the Au species exists as metallic gold (Au0). For the Au/SiO2-Fe3O4 catalyst, the BE decreases towards lower binding energy (BE=83.6eV). The deconvolution of the envelope shows two other peaks in Au 4 f 7/2 which are associated with Au0 (BE=83.8eV) and Au δ− (BE=83.12eV) species, respectively. The shift of the Au 4f binding energy to lower values suggests a negative charge on the Au atoms. Horváth et al. [25] assumed that a decrease from 84.3 to 83.9eV in BE for Au/Fe2O3 catalysts was caused by a change of Au δ+ at Au δ̄ species involving O2 species; similar decreases of BE have been observed in Au–Pd catalysts [26]. The Au/SiO2 spectrum is more complex, and the lower BE of Au 4f 7/2 is more evident in two envelopes at 83.58 and 82.57eV, which are associated with Aů and Au δ− species, respectively. Claus et al. [13] found a similar value (BE=83.2eV) for Au/SiO2 catalysts prepared by chemical vapor deposition. An electron transfer does not explain the low binding energy of Au 4f 7/2 electrons, as SiO2 is a non-reducible oxide. However, it should be considered that the gold particles are nearly spherical for Au/SiO2 [12,13], and, due to this fact, a lower binding energy of the Au 4f 7/2 electrons can be expected [13]. Chakarova et al. [11] and Rojas et al. [12] also demonstrated the presence of Au δ− charged species for Au/SiO2 prepared by deposition–precipitation with NH4OH. This process is favored in the presence of hydrogen. Table 4 shows the surface atomic ratios obtained by XPS analysis. It can be seen that the surface (Au/Fe) ratio in the Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 catalyst is higher than the corresponding atomic surface of Au/Fe3O4. This may be indicative that even the surface area of Fe3O4-SiO2 is large which allows better dispersion of Au. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation Fig. 7 shows the evolution of conversion on time during the hydrogenation of m-DNB over the Au catalyst. All of the catalysts showed a higher conversion. Au/Fe3O4 reached a maximum conversion at 2h, while this occurred for Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 and Au/SiO2 at 3 and 4h, respectively. A more appropriate comparison of the activity requires the rate constants for all systems to be determined [27]. Table 5 shows the pseudo first order rate constants of hydrogenation to m-NA (k 1) and hydrogenation to m-PDA (k 2), which were calculated assuming that the contribution of other intermediates is not significant. The values of k 1 demonstrated that the hydrogenation of m-NA to m-PDA is the limiting step of the reaction. The products obtained were expressed in terms of yield of product (Y, %) at distinct times of reaction (Table 6 ). It can be seen that the principal products observed in the experimental conditions were m-nitroaniline (m-NA), m-phenylenediamine (m-PDA), and others to a minor extent, which were considered intermediates. The sum of all the intermediates was considered hydroxylamines (m-HA), which were present in Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 and Au/Fe3O4 to a minor extent. The formation of m-NA and m-PDA is highly dependent on the support used. Fig. 8 displays the level of conversion with respect to the yield of m-NA (Fig. 8(a)) and m-PDA (Fig. 8(b)). In all catalysts, the higher conversion reached for the formation of m-NA was 80% with a yield close to 50%. Only when the conversion was close to 80%, a sharp increase was observed corresponding to the formation of m-DPA. The hydrogenation of m-DNB is explained by the electronic character of the nanoscale of Au. In this study, the solids were reduced in an H2 atmosphere to ensure the formation of Au δ− sites, and the preferential hydrogenation of m-PDA was shown, as described by Cardenas et al. [6,7]. Although the behavior of the catalysts is similar (Fig. 8), some aspects should be considered: XPS results suggest the presence of Au0 and Au δ− sites in the Au catalysts. For Au/Fe3O4, only Au0 was evidenced, while for Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 and Au/SiO2, both Au0 and Au δ− sites were encountered, meaning that the formation of Au δ− sites was more evident in the case of Au/SiO2 (lower BE of peak of Au 4f 7/2). The formation of a higher amount of Au δ− sites could be explained due to the value of k 1 being almost three times higher in Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 compared to that of Au/SiO2; however, the value of k 2 follows the opposite trend, being one order higher in Au/SiO2 (Table 4). On the other hand, the role of Fe n+ sites in the hydrogenation of m-DNB should also be considered; it appears that for Au/Fe3O4 and Au/Fe3O4-SiO2, the principal role is to decrease the intermediates, mainly hydroxylamines (m-HA) (Table 4). Hartfelder et al. [28] demonstrated by IR spectroscopy measurements that the adsorption of nitrobenzene on Au/TiO2 and Au/Al2O3 occurs through hydrogen-bonding interactions with surface hydroxyl groups on the metal oxide and through other (e.g., Lewis acid) surface sites. The presence of Fe n+ cationic sites and active Au/FeO x interfaces that are not present in Au/SiO2 catalysts provides active Lewis sites for the Au/Fe3O4 catalyst where the adsorption of m-DNB occurs. These iron sites, in combination with gold sites, are responsible for the observed catalytic activity demonstrated for Au/Fe3O4. Besides, from the XPS results, the Au/Fe ratio is higher for Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 than that for Au/Fe3O4, which can be explained considering that that the encapsulation process of the magnetic microspheres with SiO2 not was fully complete, and thus, some Fe n+ sites provided additional sites for the adsorption of molecules. On the other hand, the reuse of Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 was examined after 4 reaction cycles (Fig. 9 ). At the end of each reaction, the catalyst particles remained active and were easily separated from the product using a neodium magnet. This result shows that the catalytic activity of this catalyst decreased only slightly after reuse, while the yields of m-NA and m-PDA were maintained. 4 Conclusions Gold nanoparticles deposited on Fe3O4, Fe3O4-SiO2, and SiO2 promote the hydrogenation of m-DNB to m-PDA. The catalysts showed high yields of m-PDA. In short reaction times, the formation of m-NA was possible along with the subsequent hydrogenation to m-PDA, which required a higher amount of Au δ− sites for the selective formation of m-PDA. The presence of Fe n+ sites decreased the formation of intermediates, mainly hydroxylamines (m-HA). The Au/Fe3O4 and Au/Fe3O4-SiO2 catalysts are fully magnetically separable and easily recyclable. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic hydrogenation of m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB) was studied using Au catalysts supported on oxides with magnetic properties. The catalysts were characterized by magnetic susceptibility measurements, XRD, N2 adsorption, TPR, and XPS analysis. The results showed that the gold nanoparticles supported on Fe3O4-SiO2 led to the formation of Au δ– sites. However, this type of site did not alter the catalytic behavior. The catalysts showed high activity and were easily separable. The presence of Fe n+ sites prevented the formation of intermediate hydroxylamines.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogenation of m-dinitrobenzene over Au catalysts on magnetic supports
